title: Do boys need male role models? Gender Identities and Practices in Work with Young Men
abstractText:
The study explores what the concept of male role models means to young men in contact with welfare services and the professionals and volunteers who work with them. It will examine whether the gender identity of the worker makes a difference to developing good quality relationships and how gender interacts with others aspects of identity such as class and ethnicity. 

In partnership with a national charity, Action for Children, it will explore professional relationships with boys and young men in a range of projects catering for diverse needs and vulnerabilities. It aims to contribute to academic and policy debates and to suggest ways of improving professional practice. The study will include focus groups and individual interviews with young male service users, interviews with male and female workers, and an analysis of policy documents, media stories and academic texts covering the role of gender in work with young men. The study has received provisional ethical approval from the Open University Human Research Ethics Committee.
